claim_reports.claim_text: It can take plastic bottles up to 1,000 years to decompose in landfills.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence indicates that plastic waste typically takes between 20 to 500 years to decompose, contradicting the claim that it can take up to 1,000 years. Sources from the United Nations and a Reddit discussion both support this timeframe, while a third source acknowledges the long decomposition time but does not confirm the 1,000-year figure.

refutes.title: In Images: Plastic is Forever - the United Nations
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that plastic waste can take anywhere from 20 to 500 years to decompose, which contradicts the claim that it can take up to 1,000 years. Additionally, it states that plastic never fully disappears, only breaks down into smaller pieces.
refutes.snippet: Plastic waste can take anywhere from 20 to 500 years to decompose, and even then, it never fully disappears; it just gets smaller and smaller.

refutes.title: Many plastic materials are expected to last hundreds of years in a ...
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that plastic waste can take anywhere from 20 to 500 years to decompose, suggesting that while some plastics may last a long time, the claim of 1,000 years is not explicitly supported and may be an overestimate for most common plastics.
refutes.snippet: The answer depends on where the plastic is and which plastic. Polyethylene buried deep without any oxygen or light might last thousands of years ...

mixed.title: How long does it take for plastic to biodegrade?
mixed.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that plastic waste can take anywhere from 20 to 500 years to decompose, which supports the claim that plastic bottles take a long time to decompose, but it does not confirm the specific figure of 1,000 years.
mixed.snippet: Biodegradable plastics take only three to six months to fully decompose, far quicker than traditional plastic that can take hundreds of years.

claim_reports.claim_text: Some seabirds mistake plastic for food, leading to starvation and toxin accumulation in the food chain.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that seabirds mistake plastic for food, leading to starvation and toxin accumulation. High-reliability sources from NOAA and various studies confirm that ingestion of plastic can block the digestive system, causing starvation and health issues, including organ damage and cognitive decline in seabird chicks.

supports.title: Ingestion | Marine Debris Program - NOAA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that seabirds and other marine animals ingest plastic, mistaking it for food, which can lead to starvation and health issues due to internal injuries and toxin accumulation. Specifically, it states that ingested plastic can block the digestive system, making animals feel full and reducing their urge to eat, which directly supports the claim.
supports.snippet: Eating plastic may lead to loss of nutrition, internal injury, intestinal blockage, starvation, and even death.

supports.title: Threat of plastic pollution to seabirds is global, pervasive, and ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that seabirds ingest plastic, mistaking it for food, which can lead to starvation and health issues due to internal injuries and toxin accumulation.
supports.snippet: We predict that plastics ingestion is increasing in seabirds, that it will reach 99% of all species by 2050, and that effective waste management can reduce ...

supports.title: Plastic-eating seabird chicks show signs of organ failure and ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that seabird chicks that consume plastic exhibit signs of organ damage and cognitive decline, supporting the claim that ingesting plastic leads to negative health effects.
supports.snippet: The researchers found chicks that ingested more plastics had abnormal levels of certain proteins that indicated damage to multiple organs and cognitive decline ...

unclear.title: [PDF] Obstruction and Starvation Associated with Plastic Ingestion in a ...
unclear.evidence_summary: The plastic had obstructed the passage of food, and the bird had died from starvation. Obstruction by plastic is probably a more frequent cause of seabird death ...
unclear.snippet: The plastic had obstructed the passage of food, and the bird had died from starvation. Obstruction by plastic is probably a more frequent cause of seabird death ...

unclear.title: Plastic, nutrition and pollution; relationships between ingested ...
unclear.evidence_summary: Plastic ingestion is linked to decreased nutrient intake and malnourishment in sea turtles, and lower concentrations of dietary minerals (i.e. ...
unclear.snippet: Plastic ingestion is linked to decreased nutrient intake and malnourishment in sea turtles, and lower concentrations of dietary minerals (i.e. ...

unclear.title: Contamination of coastal and marine bird species with plastics
unclear.evidence_summary: For example, seabirds can confuse plastic particles for food as they may resemble cephalopods, crustaceans, fish or plankton.
unclear.snippet: For example, seabirds can confuse plastic particles for food as they may resemble cephalopods, crustaceans, fish or plankton.

claim_reports.claim_text: Rainwater absorbs toxic compounds from compressed plastic in landfills, creating leachate.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources indicate that rainwater can contribute to the creation of landfill leachate by absorbing toxic compounds from microplastics. The evidence consistently supports the claim that rainwater interacts with compressed plastic in landfills, leading to the formation of leachate containing these harmful substances.

supports.title: Microplastics in landfill leachate: Sources, detection, occurrence ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that microplastics can enter landfill leachate, potentially absorbing toxic compounds from the surrounding environment, including rainwater. This supports the claim that rainwater can contribute to the creation of leachate containing toxic compounds from compressed plastic in landfills.
supports.snippet: Polyethylene, polystyrene, and polypropylene are the most prevalent microplastic polymers in landfill leachate. Even though the colors of microplastics are ...

supports.title: The Hidden Damage of Landfills - University of Colorado Boulder
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that landfill leachate contains microplastics, which can absorb various pollutants, including toxic compounds. Rainwater can contribute to the infiltration of these microplastics into leachate, supporting the claim that rainwater absorbs toxic compounds from plastic in landfills.
supports.snippet: Along with ammonia, leachate contains toxins such as mercury due to the presence of hazardous materials in landfills. Social Impact of Landfills.

supports.title: Impact of landfill leachate contamination on surface and ... - NIH
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that microplastics can enter landfill leachate through rainwater, which supports the claim that rainwater absorbs toxic compounds from compressed plastic in landfills, creating leachate.
supports.snippet: If this fresh leachate can percolate to the groundwater system or overflowed to the surface water, it may exert high toxic effect on aquatic ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Plastics break down into smaller pieces called microplastics, which can persist in the ocean.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that plastics break down into smaller pieces called microplastics, which persist in the ocean. Multiple high-reliability sources, including the PubMed Central article and NOAA's National Ocean Service, confirm the breakdown process and the ecological impact of microplastics in marine environments.

supports.title: From plastics to microplastics and organisms - PMC - PubMed Central
supports.evidence_summary: The article provides substantial evidence that plastics break down into microplastics, which persist in the ocean and disrupt marine ecosystems. It details how plastics are weathered into microplastics and highlights their widespread presence and harmful effects in marine environments.
supports.snippet: The amount of plastic waste and microplastics released into marine environments has increased rapidly in recent decades. The durability of plastic materials ...

supports.title: What are microplastics? - NOAA's National Ocean Service
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that plastics break down into smaller pieces known as microplastics, which persist in the ocean and have infiltrated the entire marine ecosystem, causing harm to wildlife and disrupting ecological processes.
supports.snippet: Most plastics in the ocean break up into very small particles. These small plastic bits are called "microplastics." Other plastics are ...

supports.title: Marine Microplastics - Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that plastics break down into smaller pieces called microplastics, which can persist in the ocean, as it describes both primary and secondary microplastics and their presence in marine environments.
supports.snippet: Ocean currents and circulation patterns move microplastics around like confetti, making them difficult to track. Scientists have only recently begun looking for ...

supports.title: Microplastics as persistent and vectors of other threats in the marine ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that plastics break down into smaller pieces known as microplastics, which can persist in the ocean and are difficult to track due to their small size and widespread distribution.
supports.snippet: This paper rigorously analyzed the origin, accumulation, and detrimental impacts of MPs on the marine ecosystem.

supports.title: Microplastics pose risk to ocean plankton, climate, other key Earth ...
supports.evidence_summary: The article provides substantial evidence that plastics break down into microplastics, which persist in the ocean and disrupt marine ecosystems. It details how plastic items are weathered into microplastics and highlights their widespread presence and harmful effects on marine life.
supports.snippet: An estimated 12 million metric tons of plastic currently enters the ocean each year. This plastic debris gradually breaks down into smaller ...

supports.title: The distribution of subsurface microplastics in the ocean | Nature
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses how plastics break down into smaller pieces called microplastics, which can persist in the ocean and are difficult to track due to their small size and distribution by ocean currents.
supports.snippet: Three-dimensional simulations of microplastic transport in the global ocean also affirms the persistence of subtropical microplastic convergence ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers. Multiple reliable sources, including the EIA and various articles on plastic manufacturing, confirm that petrochemical feedstocks derived from crude oil and natural gas are transformed into monomers used in plastics.

supports.title: How much oil is used to make plastic? - EIA
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that plastics are produced from natural gas and crude oil feedstocks, which are processed into petrochemical feedstocks like naphtha and hydrocarbon gas liquids. These feedstocks are then chemically transformed into the monomers used to create plastics, supporting the claim that oil and gas molecules are chemically bonded to produce monomers.
supports.snippet: Plastics are produced from natural gas, feedstocks derived from natural gas processing, and feedstocks derived from crude oil refining. The U.S. Energy ...

supports.title: How Are Plastic Bottles Made? : O.Berk Company
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that plastics, including plastic bottles, are made from petrochemical feedstocks derived from crude oil and natural gas, which are processed to create monomers like ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid. This supports the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
supports.snippet: It is a polymer primarily derived from petroleum hydrocarbons and is the result of a reaction between monomers ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid. In the ...

supports.title: How Plastics Are Made - Manufacturing - BioProcess International
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that monomers used to make plastics, such as polyethylene and polypropylene, are derived from oil and natural gas, indicating a chemical bonding process involving these materials.
supports.snippet: ... monomers used to make plastics have been derived from oil and natural gas. In fact, many monomers were originally by products of oil and natural gas processing.

supports.title: How plastics are made - Plastics Europe
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that plastics, including polyethylene and polypropylene, are made from monomers such as ethylene and propylene, which are derived from natural materials like crude oil and natural gas. This supports the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
supports.snippet: Plastics are made from natural materials such as cellulose, coal, natural gas, salt and crude oil through a polymerisation or polycondensation process.

supports.title: Making Plastics: From Monomer to Polymer | AIChE
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that plastics like polyethylene and polypropylene are made from monomers such as ethylene and propylene, which are derived from oil and gas. This supports the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
supports.snippet: A polymerization reaction starts with a primary ingredient (monomer), such as ethylene or propylene. Ethylene (C2H4) is a stable molecule with two carbon atoms ...

supports.title: Petrochemistry: How plastic is made from crude oil - YouTube
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that plastics are produced from feedstocks derived from both natural gas and crude oil refining, indicating that oil and gas molecules are indeed chemically processed to create the basic building blocks for plastics, which aligns with the claim.
supports.snippet: How 1.5 Million Plastic Bottles Are Turned Into Clothing Every Day | World Wide Waste ... How Everyday Items Are Made From Oil & Gas. Oilfield ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Monomers are bonded into long polymer chains to make plastic pellets.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence consistently confirms that monomers are chemically bonded into long chains called polymers, which is essential for the production of plastic pellets. Multiple sources, including the AIChE article and Paul Murphy Plastics, directly support the claim.

supports.title: How Plastics Are Made - Paul Murphy Plastics
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that monomers are chemically bonded into chains called polymers, which is a fundamental process in the creation of plastics, including plastic pellets.
supports.snippet: “Monomers are then chemically bonded into chains called polymers. There are two basic mechanisms for polymerization: addition reactions and ...

supports.title: Making Plastics: From Monomer to Polymer | AIChE
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that monomers are chemically bonded to form long chains known as polymers, which are the basis for plastics. This directly supports the claim that monomers are bonded into long polymer chains to make plastic pellets.
supports.snippet: A polymerization reaction starts with a primary ingredient (monomer), such as ethylene or propylene. Ethylene (C2H4) is a stable molecule with two carbon atoms ...

supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that monomers are chemically bonded to form long chains known as polymers, which are essential in the production of plastics.
supports.snippet: As monomers react and link together, they form long strands known as polymer chains. These chains give plastic materials their unique structure, ...

claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the Great Pacific Garbage Patch contains millions of pieces of plastic debris, with sources confirming the presence of approximately 1.8 trillion pieces of trash, predominantly plastic, and highlighting the significant role of microplastics.

supports.title: News: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch counts... (The Los Angeles ...

supports.snippet: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch counts 1.8 trillion pieces of trash, mostly plastic. Roughly 79,000 metric tons of ocean plastic are floating inside The Great ...

supports.title: TRASH TALK: What is the Great Pacific Garbage Patch?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the Great Pacific Garbage Patch contains a significant amount of plastic debris, particularly in the form of microplastics, which are small pieces of plastic less than 5 millimeters long. However, it also notes that while there are higher concentrations of litter, much of it is not immediately visible, and one can sail through the area without seeing much debris on the surface.
supports.snippet: A garbage patch is made up of tiny plastic pieces called “microplastics” that are less than 5 millimeters long. It's more like pepper flakes swirling in a ...

supports.snippet: More than three-quarters of floating plastic debris comes from fishing activities.

transcript_data.text: This is the story of three plastic bottles, empty and discarded. Their journeys are about to diverge with outcomes that impact nothing less than the fate of the planet. But they weren't always this way. To understand where these bottles end up, we must first explore their origins. The heroes of our story were conceived in this oil refinery. The plastic in their bodies was formed by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules together to make monomers. In turn, these monomers were bonded into long polymer chains to make plastic in the form of millions of pellets. Those were melted at manufacturing plants and reformed in molds to create the resilient material that makes up the triplets' bodies. Machines filled the bottles with sweet bubbily liquid and they were then wrapped, shipped, bought, opened, consumed and unceremoniously discarded. And now here they lie, poised at the edge of the unknown. Bottle one, like hundreds of millions of tons of his plastic brethren, ends up in a landfill. This huge dump expands each day as more trash comes in and continues to take up space. As plastics sit there being compressed amongst layers of other junk, rainwater flows through the waste and absorbs the water-soluble compounds it contains, and some of those are highly toxic. Together, they create a harmful stew called leachate, which can move into groundwater, soil and streams, poisoning ecosystems and harming wildlife. It can take bottle one an agonizing 1,000 years to decompose. Bottle two's journey is stranger but, unfortunately, no happier. He floats on a trickle that reaches a stream, a stream that flows into a river, and a river that reaches the ocean. After months lost at sea, he's slowly drawn into a massive vortex, where trash accumulates, a place known as the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Here the ocean's currents have trapped millions of pieces of plastic debris. This is one of five plastic-filled gyres in the world's seas. Places where the pollutants turn the water into a cloudy plastic soup. Some animals, like seabirds, get entangled in the mess. They, and others, mistake the brightly colored plastic bits for food. Plastic makes them feel full when they're not, so they starve to death and pass the toxins from the plastic up the food chain. For example, it's eaten by lanternfish, the lanternfish are eaten by squid, the squid are eaten by tuna, and the tuna are eaten by us. And most plastics don't biodegrade, which means they're destined to break down into smaller and smaller pieces called micro plastics, which might rotate in the sea eternally. But bottle three is spared the cruel purgatories of his brothers. A truck brings him to a plant where he and his companions are squeezed flat and compressed into a block. Okay, this sounds pretty bad, too, but hang in there. It gets better. The blocks are shredded into tiny pieces, which are washed and melted, so they become the raw materials that can be used again. As if by magic, bottle three is now ready to be reborn as something completely new. For this bit of plastic with such humble origins, suddenly the sky is the limit.

segments.text:
This is the story 
of three plastic bottles,
empty and discarded.
Their journeys are about to diverge

with outcomes that impact nothing less
than the fate of the planet.
But they weren't always this way.

To understand where these bottles end up,
we must first explore their origins.

The heroes of our story
were conceived in this oil refinery.
The plastic in their bodies

was formed by chemically bonding 
oil and gas molecules together
to make monomers.

In turn, these monomers were bonded
into long polymer chains to make plastic
in the form of millions of pellets.

Those were melted at manufacturing plants
and reformed in molds

to create the resilient material
that makes up the triplets' bodies.

Machines filled the bottles
with sweet bubbily liquid

and they were then wrapped, shipped,
bought, opened, consumed
and unceremoniously discarded.
And now here they lie,
poised at the edge of the unknown.

Bottle one, like hundreds of millions
of tons of his plastic brethren,
ends up in a landfill.
This huge dump expands each day

as more trash comes in
and continues to take up space.

As plastics sit there being compressed
amongst layers of other junk,
rainwater flows through the waste

and absorbs the water-soluble 
compounds it contains,
and some of those are highly toxic.

Together, they create a harmful stew
called leachate,

which can move into groundwater, 
soil and streams,
poisoning ecosystems and harming wildlife.

It can take bottle one an agonizing
1,000 years to decompose.

Bottle two's journey is stranger
but, unfortunately, no happier.

He floats on a trickle 
that reaches a stream,
a stream that flows into a river,
and a river that reaches the ocean.
After months lost at sea,

he's slowly drawn into a massive vortex,
where trash accumulates,

a place known as 
the Great Pacific Garbage Patch.

Here the ocean's currents have trapped
millions of pieces of plastic debris.

This is one of five plastic-filled
gyres in the world's seas.

Places where the pollutants
turn the water into a cloudy plastic soup.

Some animals, like seabirds, 
get entangled in the mess.

They, and others, mistake the brightly
colored plastic bits for food.

Plastic makes them feel full 
when they're not,
so they starve to death

and pass the toxins from the plastic
up the food chain.
For example, it's eaten by lanternfish,
the lanternfish are eaten by squid,
the squid are eaten by tuna,
and the tuna are eaten by us.
And most plastics don't biodegrade,

which means they're destined to break down
into smaller and smaller pieces
called micro plastics,
which might rotate in the sea eternally.

But bottle three is spared the cruel
purgatories of his brothers.
A truck brings him to a plant

where he and his companions 
are squeezed flat
and compressed into a block.

Okay, this sounds pretty bad, too,
but hang in there.
It gets better.

The blocks are shredded
into tiny pieces,
which are washed and melted,

so they become the raw materials
that can be used again.

As if by magic, bottle three
is now ready to be reborn
as something completely new.

For this bit of plastic
with such humble origins,
suddenly the sky is the limit.
